displayed_text: Patient: Right, that’s what I was thinking originally, Family Member: And see what happens with medication. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Um, now about the uh hormone shots. So he’s covered for three months. After that expires he should get another shot and you start chemo? Doctor: He will have another shot, so it should be in here already. I will put it in. Family Member: In January. Doctor: So if you’ve already got an appointment for January – Family Member: January thirty. Doctor: Yeah, that will be your next shot. So typically I schedule that no matter what. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’re always going to come in and see me or (says name) Family Member: Okay.

Patient: I’ve got several questions for ya now. If I get the drug, what are the most common side effects? Doctor: I would say, fatigue. Patient: Fatigue? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. It’s kind of, it’s a little bit of a weird fatigue. You know? Like sometimes your brain’s okay, but your body doesn’t want to get off the couch. So you can’t really yell at him that much if that happens. But if it’s too much on the couch, then we’re going to have to, you know, reduce the number of pills. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, yeah. Patient: And if I am on the drug- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: How soon would I feel any? Doctor: Probably about three weeks. Patient: About three weeks? Doctor: Um hum. Yeah. Patient: So I should be good for three weeks anyway?

Patient: You know? So I mean you know I went for years without pain and when my back started hurting again I just that’s the first place I went. Doctor: Of course. Patient: You know, uh, but, uh. Healthcare Professional: Ask them to do soft tissue. I don’t know if they do soft tissue techniques but anything soft tissue… Patient: They got, you know, but I would look into masseuse a um. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Now the chemo, you know, we weren’t going to do any trial just once every three weeks over an hour. Totally doable. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you know I never just do the standard routine anything. (Laughs) Patient: I been here long enough, I just, I am not new here. Doctor: Yes. So there is uh you know the trial is two-thirds of the people get vitamin C, Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: high dose. So this stuff comes out of Hopkins you know from a special company. It took us forever to do it. But the grade of vitamin C is great.

Patient: No chemo drug, though? Doctor: It is more of a natural product, biologic drug that on, um, in animals and in cell lines looks active against prostate cancer. And, so, now they’re escalating the dose of this natural product. Um. Family Member: Is that, uh, a stem cell or cell therapy or is it a -- Doctor: No, it comes like from a, I--I’d have to look. Whether it comes from a seed cucumber or-- Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or a pine co—Oh, it’s—I’d have to look it up. But, it’s, it’s a natural thing that, that, they have --- Patient: It’s organic medicine. Doctor: Right. You know, we’ve done studies with pomegranates and muscadine grapes, and it sort of extends to that sort of area. Uh, but this again is, uh, experimental. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. So, in that study, we’re looking at how you tolerate it. Uh, what’s the safe dose. Ah, and then, you know, we monitor your disease; that if it’s not getting better, then we move on. If it is improving or not - stable, you can stay with that treatment. Patient: Okay. Family Member: It’s a phase one. How long does the phase one run for? Uh, because I’m wondering if there are subsequent phases, um but Doctor: So, typically, we treat three men at a one-dose level.

Patient: Right. Doctor: He’s just so you know because I guess your family and - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - his family are all sort of active, you know he’s very happy to you know be a part of that process, but also if you’re getting it locally and getting it done - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, so I’m not going to put any additional appointments in here. I’ll let D take it over from here. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let me see if she’s out here to sort of get a sense that I can give you some feedback that it will be in the next day or the next week to sort of say to you - Patient: And then you will let us know about chemo Doctor: Yeah, we’ve got a little bit of a window, so we probably have until early February to get started. Patient: Oh so it won’t get started before that? Doctor: No, it could start as soon as you participate in the study, we can do that, but it’s not urgent that it has to be done before Christmas or before the new year’s or before Martin Luther King - Patient: Okay.

Patient: Uh, you know, I’ve been having, you know, just like something happening, and- Doctor: But it’s not effective enough that you can have sex with it? Is that what you’re saying? Patient: Uh, well, I have, but, you know, it’s like I wanted to get better, you know, so. Doctor: Okay. So you’re able to have an erection enough that you can penetrate the vagina? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So you want to get better? Patient: Yes. So I just want to be patient. Doctor: Okay, and it may, and it very well may, because it’s just, uh, let’s see, it was done, you had the operation on-. Patient: Uh, on the fourteenth of September. Doctor: September? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So you’re not quite a year?

Patient: Right. Doctor: Are we the ones that give it to you? Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Yeah. K___ gives it. Doctor: Yeah. From us. I’m like why did I think it wasn’t us? Oh, it’s us. And you know we make your diabetes like even worse. So I feel partly responsible. I’m just trying to make sure you stay healthy. No carbs. Patient: Okay. Then, we’re going to see you, see you in six weeks? Doctor: That’s it. Enjoy yourself. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Have fun. Enjoy the weather. Patient: Let’s see. Six weeks is going to put us in middle of July? Family Member: Right. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: End of July.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: For this particular one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then next time we’ll start the new one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay and that will be uh so you’ll have to come two days in a row every three weeks. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: Okay. So as in one day you get the chemo, the second day you come in and just get that shot. Patient: Okay. I think that’s what B do. A friend of mine, I think that’s what he get. Patient: He doesn’t get a shot or nothing. Doctor: The second day? Patient: No he said it was come - I think he said it was come three times, twice, twice a month.

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But I haven’t, I don’t cure anybody with prostate cancer, so I’m getting frustrated in my career. You know? Is there something I can do that has a chance to cure the disease? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The only thing I could think of, so we’re testing the bone marrow transplant idea is being prostate. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So their immune system has not been exposed to prostate tissue. What if we used a female into a male? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: The other things we’re looking at is keeping the male castrated so all the prostate genes are turned off, and then after the new bone marrow gets all happy, you get a couple of pulse of testosterone, not to treat the cancer but to turn on the genes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: To get the immune system. This new immune system, saying what the hell is that? It’s almost like an infection. So we’re in the early stages. We’ve treated two men. I can’t say much other than you know they did pretty well with the transplant part. Uh we’re following them. It’s really designed, my idea is for younger men, you know, less than seventy, and that is younger for me, uh, where, you know, unfortunately, you know prostate cancer grows slowly in most men. You’re probably going to live long enough that this is you know could be really- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, we’re, we’re uh cautiously optimistic. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: …probably they do it here or? Doctor: We do it here but I’ll let him refer you to whom he wants to refer you to. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh no we don’t do it uh… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …we just specialize in prostate getting you better. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Okay, so we’ll do that. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And uh I want to see you in three months. Patient: Um hmm. How’s the blood. Doctor: Oh PSA. That’s the most important. Undetectable no evidence of any cancer.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think like taking a globe and a string or something and see. Patient: Yeah. I didn’t understand why- Doctor: I don’t quite understand how it’s shorter, but it’s shorter. Family Member: But we could see on the plane, you know, on the screen the pattern he’s flying in- Doctor: Yeah. You go up. Right. You go up along Canada. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: There’s a part over Canada where you cross, there’s like a big bay, I think the jet stream. It gets real choppy there. You get a lot of turbulence. I always know- Family Member: Yeah. We did. Doctor: And one time, I don’t know where I was, but I remember looking out the window. I could see Greenland. Doctor: I could see actually. Because usually when the times I’ve flown, it’s either dark or cloudy, but this is one like, holy crap, and my phone even said, welcome. Doctor: You know when you fly sometimes, your cell phone will pick up. I must not have had it turned off. It said, like welcome to Greenland. (Laughter) Patient: Oh, shoot. Oh, God.

Family Member: So he won’t get; will he – does he need nausea medication for this drug or anything? Doctor: Typically not; obviously we can, oh you know, he’s such a typical guy. But yes, Dr. ___ can prescribe that because he has a set thing because this is his program to run. So I’m just hovering nearby. Family Member: I think he was the one that actually diagnosed you with cancer when I told him to do the bone scan. Doctor: Oh my gosh! That’s been a long time then. Patient: Yes. Family Member: Yeah, because he was just going to start him on radiation and I go well - Doctor: No, he saw Dr. ___ in O____ when I was there many moons ago. Family Member: Because I told him, “His dad suffered, died from prostate cancer, could you at least do a scan on him and make sure he doesn’t have bone cancer?” And they did. Doctor: Yeah. And poof! Family Member: And bam, it showed up! Doctor: Told you you were weird. Patient: So then, yes, so then it was at that point that I went to ___ for a consult. Family Member: Uh hum, yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have done a handful of men before, and the handful of men seemed to have their PSA drop for awhile. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But, it’s not the mega excitement in prostate cancer, uh, that we see with the other tumors that you hear on the news with Jimmy Carter and all of those kinds of – Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um, it can possibly benefit people for awhile. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’ve amended it and added a new cohort, so another group of men. But, these are men that they’re last therapy, or their willingness to stay on Enzalutamide, because there’s one group, uh, that showed that maybe if you use Enzalutamide and immune therapy, you get a better response (chuckles) Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’re testing a group of men, uh, uh, with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: Well, it’s working then. Doctor: Any issues with your mood or depression? Why do you take the Wellbutrin? Patient: Well, the Wellbutrin was so I wouldn’t smoke much. Doctor: So, it’s not for your mood or depression? Patient: No. Doctor: And any issues with anxiety? Patient: No. Doctor: Acid reflux? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you still have your appendix? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Still have your gallbladder? Patient: Yes.

Patient: If it’s so good, why don’t they, why does it take so long in the U.S. then to get these? Doctor: So, in Germany, and Australia, I know they’re also doing it in Australia. I know it’s a little farther for you- Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Uh in Germany they have a law that if the doctor thinks something is beneficial it doesn’t have to be you know like you know in America, FDA approved. So the FDA, the bar is show me it makes people live longer. It’s a pretty high bar. Because that requires a lot of patients, a lot time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but at the end of the day, you feel really confident that what I’m giving you could help. Patient: Right. I got it. Doctor: What they are allowed to do there is use the material as long as they don’t try to sell it outside their hospital or use it outside the hospital, they’re allowed to do it. And the material they’re using is kind of an off-the-shelf thing where they could buy it, make it on site. Uh in the U.S. what’s gotten problematic is I think we’re on the third company now that’s tried to develop this. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: The first two companies kind of went under. It’s a little bit complicated with the drug involved because it’s radioactive. You’ve got to have a whole infrastructure. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: To make sure the radiation is here on Tuesday when you’re here. It’s not like you just go over to the pharmacy and grab it because there’s all that stuff.
